occupy.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to live or stay in a place
occupy.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: He occupies the house without paying any rent.
The building was purchased and occupied by its new owners last year.
occupy.translation[0].definitions[1].def: if something occupies you or your time, you are busy doing it
occupy.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Football occupies most of my leisure time.
Only six percent of police time is occupied with criminal incidents.
occupy.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to fill a particular amount of space
occupy.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Family photos occupied almost the entire wall.
occupy.translation[0].definitions[2].not: In everyday English, people usually say that something takes up time or space rather than occupies it:
Work takes up most of her time.
That bed takes up almost the whole room.
occupy.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to enter a place in a large group and keep control of it, especially by military force
occupy.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Students occupied Sofia University on Monday.
occupy.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to use something such as a room, seat, or bed
occupy.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: Many patients who are occupying hospital beds could be transferred to other places.
occupy.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to have an official position or job
occupy.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: Before becoming prime minister, he had already occupied several cabinet posts.
occupy.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to use a particular building to live or work in
occupy.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: a large computer company that occupies a building of some 60,000 sq ft
occupy.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to have an official position or job
occupy.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: He occupies an important position in government.
occupy.translation[1].definitions[2].def: if something is occupying you, you are busy doing it
occupy.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: As PA to the chief executive, there is plenty to keep you occupied.
Mr Ball is occupied with a customer at the moment.
occupy.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to use a particular amount of space or time
occupy.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: Computer files occupy much less storage space than paper ones.
Running the business occupies nearly all of her time.
